page.title: 01GENERAL DESCRIPTION
page.content: The village of Madeley was originally an Anglo-Saxon settlement called Madan- lieg and was mentioned in the first Domesday Book. It enjoys a good posit- ion with access to the market towns of Newcastle-under-Lyme, Crewe and Nant- wich. One feature of Madeley is the pond which supports a variety of wild life. The village has many old build- ings of character, the most impressive being the 16th century Old Hall. Much of the area still belongs to the Crewe Family estate. There have been many changes and dev- elopments in the last forty years,incl- uding two council estates, a teacher training college and three private estates, all of which have encouraged more people into the village. Madeley remains a quiet rural village, despite being flanked by the main Crewe-London railway line and the M6 Motorway.
